segment.source: Get the user's location
segment.target: Get the user's location

segment.source: Find the user's location and respond to changes in location.
segment.target: Find the user's location and respond to changes in location.

segment.source: Access to the user's location is managed by privacy settings in the Settings app.
segment.target: Access to the user's location is managed by privacy settings in the Settings app.

segment.source: This topic also shows how to check if your app has permission to access the user's location.
segment.target: This topic also shows how to check if your app has permission to access the user's location.

segment.source: Get the user's location
segment.target: Get the user's location

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Find the user's location and respond to changes in location.
segment.target: Find the user's location and respond to changes in location.

segment.source: Access to the user's location is managed by privacy settings in the Settings app.
segment.target: Access to the user's location is managed by privacy settings in the Settings app.

segment.source: This topic also shows how to check if your app has permission to access the user's location.
segment.target: This topic also shows how to check if your app has permission to access the user's location.

segment.source: Tip To learn more about accessing the user's location in your app, download the following sample from the Windows-universal-samples repo on GitHub.
segment.target: Tip To learn more about accessing the user's location in your app, download the following sample from the Windows-universal-samples repo on GitHub.

segment.source: Universal Windows Platform (UWP) map sample
segment.target: Universal Windows Platform (UWP) map sample

segment.source: Enable the location capability
segment.target: Enable the location capability

segment.source: In Solution Explorer, double-click package.appxmanifest and select the Capabilities tab.
segment.target: In Solution Explorer, double-click package.appxmanifest and select the Capabilities tab.

segment.source: In the Capabilities list, select the Capabilities tab.
segment.target: In the Capabilities list, select the Capabilities tab.

segment.source: This adds the device capability to the package manifest file.
segment.target: This adds the device capability to the package manifest file.

segment.source: Get the current location
segment.target: Get the current location

segment.source: This section describes how to detect the user's geographic location using APIs in the Windows.Devices.Geolocation namespace.
segment.target: This section describes how to detect the user's geographic location using APIs in the Windows.Devices.Geolocation namespace.

segment.source: Step 1: Request access to the user's location
segment.target: Step 1: Request access to the user's location

segment.source: Important You must request access to the user's location by using the RequestAccessAsync method before attempting to access the user's location.
segment.target: Important You must request access to the user's location by using the RequestAccessAsync method before attempting to access the user's location.

segment.source: You must call the RequestAccessAsync method from the UI thread and your app must be in the foreground.
segment.target: You must call the RequestAccessAsync method from the UI thread and your app must be in the foreground.

segment.source: Your app will not be able to access the user's location information until after the user grants permission to your app.
segment.target: Your app will not be able to access the user's location information until after the user grants permission to your app.

segment.source: The RequestAccessAsync method prompts the user for permission to access their location.
segment.target: The RequestAccessAsync method prompts the user for permission to access their location.

segment.source: The user is only prompted once (per app).
segment.target: The user is only prompted once (per app).

segment.source: After the first time they grant or deny permission, this method no longer prompts the user for permission.
segment.target: After the first time they grant or deny permission, this method no longer prompts the user for permission.

segment.source: To help the user change location permissions after they've been prompted, we recommend that you provide a link to the location settings as demonstrated later in this topic.
segment.target: To help the user change location permissions after they've been prompted, we recommend that you provide a link to the location settings as demonstrated later in this topic.

segment.source: Step 2: Get the user's location and register for changes in location permissions
segment.target: Step 2: Get the user's location and register for changes in location permissions

segment.source: The GetGeopositionAsync method performs a one-time reading of the current location.
segment.target: The GetGeopositionAsync method performs a one-time reading of the current location.

segment.source: Here, a switch statement is used with accessStatus (from the previous example) to act only when access to the user's location is allowed.
segment.target: Here, a switch statement is used with accessStatus (from the previous example) to act only when access to the user's location is allowed.

segment.source: If access to the user's location is allowed, the code creates a Geolocator object, registers for changes in location permissions, and requests the user's location.
segment.target: If access to the user's location is allowed, the code creates a Geolocator object, registers for changes in location permissions, and requests the user's location.

segment.source: Step 3: Handle changes in location permissions
segment.target: Step 3: Handle changes in location permissions

segment.source: The Geolocator object triggers the StatusChanged event to indicate that the user's location settings changed.
segment.target: The Geolocator object triggers the StatusChanged event to indicate that the user's location settings changed.

segment.source: That event passes the corresponding status via the argument's Status property (of type PositionStatus).
segment.target: That event passes the corresponding status via the argument's Status property (of type PositionStatus).

segment.source: Note that this method is not called from the UI thread and the Dispatcher object invokes the UI changes.
segment.target: Note that this method is not called from the UI thread and the Dispatcher object invokes the UI changes.

segment.source: Respond to location updates
segment.target: Respond to location updates

segment.source: This section describes how to use the PositionChanged event to receive updates of the user's location over a period of time.
segment.target: This section describes how to use the PositionChanged event to receive updates of the user's location over a period of time.

segment.source: Because the user could revoke access to location at any time, it's important call RequestAccessAsync and use the StatusChanged event as shown in the previous section.
segment.target: Because the user could revoke access to location at any time, it's important call RequestAccessAsync and use the StatusChanged event as shown in the previous section.

segment.source: This section assumes that you've already enabled the location capability and called RequestAccessAsync from the UI thread of your foreground app.
segment.target: This section assumes that you've already enabled the location capability and called RequestAccessAsync from the UI thread of your foreground app.

segment.source: Step 1: Define the report interval and register for location updates
segment.target: Step 1: Define the report interval and register for location updates

segment.source: In this example, a switch statement is used with accessStatus (from the previous example) to act only when access to the user's location is allowed.
segment.target: In this example, a switch statement is used with accessStatus (from the previous example) to act only when access to the user's location is allowed.

segment.source: If access to the user's location is allowed, the code creates a Geolocator object, specifies the tracking type, and registers for location updates.
segment.target: If access to the user's location is allowed, the code creates a Geolocator object, specifies the tracking type, and registers for location updates.

segment.source: The Geolocator object can trigger the PositionChanged event based on a change in position (distance-based tracking) or a change in time (periodic-based tracking).
segment.target: The Geolocator object can trigger the PositionChanged event based on a change in position (distance-based tracking) or a change in time (periodic-based tracking).

segment.source: For distance-based tracking, set the MovementThreshold property.
segment.target: For distance-based tracking, set the MovementThreshold property.

segment.source: For periodic-based tracking, set the ReportInterval property.
segment.target: For periodic-based tracking, set the ReportInterval property.

segment.source: If neither property is set, a position is returned every 1 second (equivalent to ).
segment.target: If neither property is set, a position is returned every 1 second (equivalent to ).

segment.source: Here, a 2 second () report interval is used.
segment.target: Here, a 2 second () report interval is used.

segment.source: Step 2: Handle location updates
segment.target: Step 2: Handle location updates

segment.source: The Geolocator object triggers the PositionChanged event to indicate that the user's location changed or time has passed, depending on how you've configured it.
segment.target: The Geolocator object triggers the PositionChanged event to indicate that the user's location changed or time has passed, depending on how you've configured it.

segment.source: That event passes the corresponding location via the argument's Position property (of type Geoposition).
segment.target: That event passes the corresponding location via the argument's Position property (of type Geoposition).

segment.source: In this example, the method is not called from the UI thread and the Dispatcher object invokes the UI changes.
segment.target: In this example, the method is not called from the UI thread and the Dispatcher object invokes the UI changes.

segment.source: Change the location privacy settings
segment.target: Change the location privacy settings

segment.source: If the location privacy settings don't allow your app to access the user's location, we recommend that you provide a convenient link to the location privacy settings in the Settings app.
segment.target: If the location privacy settings don't allow your app to access the user's location, we recommend that you provide a convenient link to the location privacy settings in the Settings app.

segment.source: In this example, a Hyperlink control is used navigate to the URI.
segment.target: In this example, a Hyperlink control is used navigate to the URI.

segment.source: Alternatively, your app can call the LaunchUriAsync method to launch the Settings app from code.
segment.target: Alternatively, your app can call the LaunchUriAsync method to launch the Settings app from code.

segment.source: For more info, see Launch the Windows Settings app.
segment.target: For more info, see Launch the Windows Settings app.

segment.source: Troubleshoot your app
segment.target: Troubleshoot your app

segment.source: Before your app can access the user's location, Location must be enabled on the device.
segment.target: Before your app can access the user's location, Location must be enabled on the device.

segment.source: In the Settings app, check that the following location privacy settings are turned on:
segment.target: In the Settings app, check that the following location privacy settings are turned on:

segment.source: Location for this device... is turned on (not applicable in Windows 10 Mobile)
segment.target: Location for this device... is turned on (not applicable in Windows 10 Mobile)

segment.source: The location services setting, Location, is turned on
segment.target: The location services setting, Location, is turned on

segment.source: Under Choose apps that can use your location, your app is set to on
segment.target: Under Choose apps that can use your location, your app is set to on
